title: Dramatic Clamshell Lighting Photo Deconstruction
summary: Lindsay Adler demonstrates a dramatic variation of the traditional clamshell lighting setup. By using hard, gridded lights instead of soft modifiers, she creates a sculpted, high-contrast portrait. The tutorial covers the three-light setup, the use of ND gels to manage strobe power, and post-processing techniques including Generative Fill.

steps.action: Position the main light above and centered on the subject to create a concentrated, hard light.
Place the fill light below the subject's face to lift shadows while maintaining directionality.
steps.tool: Profoto D2 with 1x4ft Strip Softbox + Grid

steps.action: Set up a background light on a floor stand behind the subject to create separation and a gradient.
Apply a Neutral Density (ND) gel to the background strobe to reduce its power below the minimum setting.
Adjust white balance in post-processing to warm up the image and add a magenta tint.
Use Generative Fill to clean up stray hairs and refine the hair edge.

key_takeaways: Clamshell lighting can be used for dramatic, sculpted results using hard light modifiers like grids.
A 5-degree grid creates an extremely narrow and concentrated beam of light.
ND gels are crucial for lowering the output of powerful strobes when shooting at wide apertures or low ISOs.
Hard light can be flattering and doesn't always require extensive skin retouching.
Generative Fill is highly effective for cleaning up messy hair edges in post-production.
